Fig. 2 Voltage profiles of Cu|Li half cells with electrodes coated by diffusion layers at different areal densities: (a) 3.0, (b) 6.0 and (c) 18.0 mg cm−2. Cross-sectional view of the coated electrodes revealed that lithium deposits (d) within the fiber at the areal density of 3.0 mg cm−2, and underneath the fiber at the areal densities of (e) 6.0 mg cm−2 and (f) 18.0 mg cm−2, respectively. Top view of the coated electrode at areal densities of (g) 3.0, (h) 6.0 and (i) 18.0 mg cm−2 further verified the change of deposition site with the areal density. Dendritic morphologies of lithium was observed underneath the diffusion layers with areal densities of (j) 3.0 and (l) 18.0 mg cm−2, whereas dendrite-free morphology was observed at (k) 6.0 mg cm−2. Fig. 3 EIS measurements of bare electrodes and coated electrodes with different areal densities: (a) Nyquist and Z″-frequency plots, and (b) Bode plots. SEM images of Li deposits on the bare electrodes discharged at (d) 0.1, (e) 0.5, and (f) 1.0 mAh cm−2. Zunyi 563003 Guizhou China State Key Laboratory of Advanced Chemical Power Sources, Guizhou Meiling Power Sources Co., Ltd., Zunyi 563003, Guizhou, China c School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Queen’s University Belfast, Belfast BT9 5AG, United Kingdom School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Queen’s University Belfast Belfast BT9 5AG United Kingdom School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Queen’s University Belfast, Belfast BT9 5AG, United Kingdom ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract A robust and stable artificail SEI is achieved by polysulfone fibers with optimal areal density and interfacial resistance so that deposition underneath the layer is resulted for long-term cycling and dendrite-free morphology for high Coulombic efficiency. A uniform diffusion layer is essential for non-dendritic deposition of lithium in high-density lithium batteries. However, natural pristine solid electrolyte interface (SEI) is always porous and inhomogeneous because of repeated breakdown and repair cycles, whereas ideal materials with excellent mechanical property for artificial SEIs remain a challenge. Herein, a robust and stable interface is achieved by spinning soft polymer associated with few MoO3 into fibers, and thus mechanical property of fibers other than materials determines mechanical performance of the interface which can be optimized by adjusting parameters. Furthermore, lithium deposited underneath the layer is enabled by constructing an optimal resistance to make the membrane serve as an artificial SEI rather than lithium host. As a result, dendrite-free lithium was observed underneath the membrane, and stable interface for long-term cycling was also indicated by EIS measurements. The lithium iron phosphate (LiFePO4) full-cell with coated electrode demonstrated an initial capacity of 155.2 mAh g−1, and 80% of its original capacity was retained after 500 cycles at 2.0 °C without any additive in carbonate-based electrolyte. Keywords Lithium metal battery Dendrite-free Interfacial stability Uniform diffusion layer Deposition site 1 Introduction The emerging technologies in energy storage are driven by the demand for portable devices with more active time and electric vehicles having an extended driving range [1,2]. As the commercial lithium-ion batteries (LIB) approaches its theoretical energy densities, lithium metal has been considered a potential alternative to carbon-based anode because of its high theoretical specific capacity (3860 mAh g−1) and low electrochemical potential (−3.04 V vs. the standard hydrogen electrode) [3,4]. Nevertheless, safety issues arising from uncontrolled lithium dendrites formation remain a great challenge and have become obstacles in real-life applications of lithium metal batteries (LMBs) [5,6]. It is believed that non-uniform Li-ion flux contributes to the unstable solid state interface (SEI) and is thus the critical factor in dendritic morphology of deposited lithium [7]. The SEI layer is instantaneously formed upon contact of lithium metal with the electrolyte [8]. However, it breaks easily because of its low elastic modulus in resisting the large deformations at the plating/stripping stages [9]. Thus, a porous and inhomogeneous SEI layer is always the result, which in turn determines the structure of the electrical double layer and the migration rate of Li+ ions across the SEI layer [10,11]. This is the rate-determining step of the overall chemical reaction. The anisotropy of SEI is supposed to contribute various resistances in different areas of the electrode surface and in turn yield different deposition rates while dendritic branches are generated at the sites with rapid growth rates [12]. Considerable research efforts have been devoted to generating a uniform and stable interfacial layer. Additives such as halogenated salt [13], Cs+ [14], and FEC [15], have been used to change the components and mechanical and conductive character of SEIs. Artificial SEIs have also been fabricated to address the anisotropy of in-situ SEIs. Nevertheless, inorganic SEIs like h-BN [16], Li3PO4 [17], Li6.4La3Zr1.4Ta0.6O12 [18], and Al2O3 [19] lack essential elastic moduli for volume expansion, whereas most organic ones such as β-polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) [20] and polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) [21] have demonstrated inferior ion conductivity and have inevitably resulted in increases in interfacial resistance [22,23]. Hybrid membranes are considered as promising materials that combine advantages of both inorganic and organic materials, while the degradation of phase interfaces during cycling remains a great concern [24,25]. Herein, we spin the hybrid materials into fibers so that mechanical property of fibers other than materials determines mechanical performance of the interface and can be optimized by adjusting parameters [26]. Furthermore, the Li+ ion flux would transfer through the space between fibers other than through phase interfaces in dense hybrid membrane, which help avoid long-term degradation of hybrid materials. Electrospinning technology is employed. In fact, electrospun membranes [27,28] have been applied in LMBs for year, while almost all serve as lithium host enabling uniform deposition between fibers other than underneath fibers. A lithiophilic oxidized polyacrylonitrile (PAN) has been employed as polymer matrix to improve electrochemical performances of LMBs [29]. The C=N, C=O, O−H bonds in PAN chains are expected to serve as object points for Li+ ions and to block the accumulation of Li+ ions. Thus uniform Li-ion flux and dendrite-free lithium are resulted within the polymer network, and more than 120 cycles with Coulombic efficiencies greater than 97% for Cu|Li coin cells at current densities of 1.0 and 3.0 mA cm−2 was obtained. 3D lithium electrode, fabricated by coating the electrospun PI matrix with molten lithium, leave the space between the polymer fibers for lithium deposition to eliminate volume expansion [30]. Stable cycling for more than 195 h in both carbonate-based and ether-based electrolytes at 1.0 mA cm−2 was observed. Lithiophilic-lithiophobic gradient layer constructed by electrospinning technology has also been reported to provide stable interface [31]. Since the positive effect of electrospun membranes on uniform Li+ ion flux has been proved when the membranes serve as lithium host, the performance is expected to be further improved if lithium deposition underneath the membrane is achieved [32]. However, it is hard to determine the optimal parameters so as to enable deposition underneath the layer for long-term cycling and also to ensure dendrite-free morphology for high Coulombic efficiency. In this study, the two are both realized by increasing areal density of polysulfone (PSf) fibers and incorporation of molybdenum oxide (MoO3) as anchoring sites to avoid excessive overpotential (Scheme 1 ). The hybrid membrane results in resistance for the transport of Li+ ions (R dl), which is much higher and more stable than that of SEI layer (R SEI). As a result, the electrospun PSf/MoO3 hybrid membrane with optimal resistance is expected to result in uniform Li-ion flux for the subsequent reduction reaction. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials PSf was supplied by Sigma-Aldrich Chemical Co., Ltd. and used to fabricate the fiber matrix. MoO3 powder with a 99.5% metals basis was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Chemical Co., Ltd. and employed as the additive that interacts with Li+ ions in the electrolyte. The spinning solution consisted of N,N-dimethyl acetamide (DMAc, Sigma-Aldrich Chemical Co., Ltd.) and acetone (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.) with a mass ratio of 3:1. LiFePO4 (Pulead Technology Industry Co., Ltd.), PVDF (Solef-5130) and super P (C-65, TIMCAL Graphite & Carbon Co., Ltd.) were utilized to prepare the LiFePO4 electrode. The Li metal foil and electrolytes used in the study were purchased from China Energy Lithium Co., Ltd. and DoDo Chem Co., Ltd., respectively. 2.2 Electrode preparation The PSf/MoO3 hybrid fiber was fabricated using the electrospinning method. PSf (1.2 g) were dissolved in 2.6 g of spinning solution to produce the polymer precursor solution, and 3.0 wt%, 5.0 wt%, 8.0 wt% MoO3 nanoparticles (denoted as PSf/MoO3-3, PSf/MoO3-5, PSf/MoO3-8, respectively) were added to the polymer solution as additives. After being stirred for 8 h at room temperature, the polymer solution was transferred to an injector and delivered by a syringe pump. The metal needle of the injector was connected to a DC power supply with a high voltage of 15 kV. The solution was sprayed at a flow rate of 25 μL min−1. A rotating collector was employed to collect the fiber, and the distance between the needle and collector was maintained at 12 cm. The areal density of obtained nanofiber is 6.0 mg cm−2. The residual solvent in the fiber was removed by vacuum heating at 50 °C for 24 h. After being punched onto a disk with an 18-mm diameter, the membrane was directly coated on the electrode surface and labeled as a coated electrode. PSf/MoO3-5 nanofibers with different areal densities of 3.0, 6.0, and 18.0 mg cm−2 were obtained by adjusting the total injection volume to evaluate the effect of areal density on electrochemical properties. 2.3 Characterizations The function groups of the PSf granule was verified by Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR, Thermo IS5). X-ray diffractometer (XRD, Bruker D8 Venture) and Raman spectroscopy (Renishaw inVia Raman microscope) were employed to characterize the crystallinity of MoO3. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM, FEI Quanta FEG 250) was applied to observe the morphology of the PSf/MoO3 hybrid fiber. 2.4 Electrochemical measurements The two electrode cell configurations were assembled as 2025 coin-type cells in an Ar-filled glove box with H2O and O2 content of less than 0.1 ppm. Celgard 2400 was used as the separator for both cell systems. Cu|Li half-cells consisted of a Cu foil coated by a PSf/MoO3 hybrid fiber as the cathode and Li foil as the anode. Li|Li symmetry cells were assembled with coated Li foil to function as both the cathode and anode. The electrolytes of the Cu|Li half-cells and Li|Li symmetry cells were 1.0-M lithium bis (trifluor-omethanesulfonyl) imide (LiTFSI) dissolved in 1,3-dioxolane and 1,2-dimethoxyethane (1:1 by volume) with 2.0% LiNO3 as an additive. The LiFePO4 cathodes of LiFePO4|Li full-cells were composed of LiFePO4, PVDF, and Super P at a mass ratio of 8:1:1. In addition, the coated Li foils were used as the anodes of full-cells. For the electrolytes of full-cells, 1.0-M LiPF6 in ethylene carbonate and diethyl carbonate (1:1 by volume) were employed without any additives. The Li deposit on the coated electrodes was demonstrated by SEM. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was conducted on EC-Lab software with a frequency varying from 100 kHz to 20 mHz under 5 mV amplitude. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Morphology and structural properties of the PSf/MoO3 fiber SEM was employed to observe the morphology of the as-prepared PSf/MoO3 hybrid membrane. Fig. 1 (a, b) showed that the diameters of PSf fibers range between 1.0 and 2.0 μm. The MoO3 nanoparticles were uniformly dispersed in the PSf fibers (Fig. 1a, b and S1), which were expected to facilitate the diffusion of Li+ ion via electron–ion interactions through abundant Mo–O bonds on the surface [33]. With an areal density of 6.0 mg cm−2, the membrane obtained a thickness of 30 μm (Fig. 1c). The cross-sectional image (Fig. 1c) showed that the fibers were interwoven forming a highly porous network. The stacked fibers shrank the active area of the electrode/electrolyte interface and Li+ ions transport was also confined. The functional group of the PSf was determined by FT-IR (Fig. 1d). The characteristic peaks at 1585, 1490, 1235, and 1015 cm−1 were assigned to the stretching mode of the benzene ring, asymmetric stretching vibration of the sulfonyl group, and asymmetric stretching vibration of aromatic ether [34,35]. The benzene ring in the backbone supports the intrinsic rigidity of the polymer and enables the PSf to possess excellent mechanical performance. XRD and Raman spectra were employed to determine the crystal structure of MoO3. The diffraction peak at 2θ of 12.8°, 23.9°, 27.4°, and 39.0° as shown in Fig. 1(e) were assigned to diffraction planes (020), (040), (021), and (060), respectively [36]. These diffraction peaks correspond to the orthorhombic α-MoO3 according to JCPDS database number 01–0706. The peaks of the other phases were not detected, indicating the purity of α-MoO3 nanoparticles [37]. In addition, the diffraction planes of (020), (040), and (060) revealed that the α-MoO3 preferred to orient in the [001] direction, thus forming a layered structure [38]. The typical peaks as shown in Fig. 1(f) at 667, 819, and 996 cm−1 were indexed to Mo3–O stretching, Mo2–O stretching, and Mo=O stretching, respectively [39]. The Raman result further demonstrated the orthorhombic phase of α-MoO3 [40]. It is known that the orthorhombic α-MoO3 is the most thermodynamically stable phase and that the layered structure promotes it accommodates more lithium ions than do other types of structures [36]. 3.2 Determination of the optimal areal density and MoO3 fraction The PSf/MoO 3 hybrid membrane was applied to the Li anode, thus acting as an artificial SEI layer to further increase the polarization voltage and subsequently to construct a uniform diffusion layer near the electrode surface [41,42]. Note that the optimal polarization voltage associated with the areal density of the electrospun membrane must be determined in an initial study. Cu|Li half-cells were assembled and cycled at 1.0 mA cm−2 and 1.0 mAh cm−2. Coated electrodes with different areal densities (3.0, 6.0, and 18.0 mg cm−2) of electrospun membranes were utilized. The polarization voltages of Cu|Li half-cells demonstrated a positive correlation on the areal density (Fig. 2 a-c). The electrodes coated with membranes with an areal density of 3.0 and 6.0 mg cm−2 resulted in an average overpotential of approximately 30 mV (Fig. 2a) and 38 mV (Fig. 2b), respectively, which was just slightly higher than that of the bare electrode (29 mV). As the areal density increased to 18.0 mg cm−2, the overpotential was shown to be 47 mV higher than that of the bare electrode (Fig. 2c). The stacked fibers in the artificial SEI occupied the partial active areal for Li+ ion migration, thus increasing the interfacial resistance and overpotential. In addition, the thickness of the membrane did not increase in direct proportion to the areal density (Fig. 2d-f), indicating an implicit increase in weave density and a decrease in pore size, both of which are closely related to the total resistance of the membrane to diffusion and electrochemical reaction. The weave density contributed positively to the tortuosity factor of the diffusion pathway, whereas considerable resistance along the pores was shown even in high-conductivity electrolytes, because the cross section of the pores was much less than the geometric dimensions of the electrode. Increased areal density changed the deposition sites of lithium from within the fibers to underneath the membrane. Under lower areal density, Li atoms were deposited at the space between the polymer fibers other than that between the membrane and electrode (Fig. 2d). When the areal density was increased to 6.0 and 18.0 mg cm−2, Li atoms tended to deposit underneath the coated membrane (Fig. 2e, f). The top view of the membrane further demonstrated the change in lithium deposition sites. The surface of the membrane with an areal density of 3.0 mg cm−2 was partly covered by the deposited lithium metal, indicating a continuous deposition of lithium from the surface of the electrode to that of the membrane (Fig. 2g). By contrast, no lithium deposits were found on the surface of the membrane with enhanced areal density (Fig. 2h, i). The deposition site and overpotential are the critical factors that influence the morphology of deposited lithium. In the plating stage, MoO3 nanoparticles in the fibers assist the diffusion of Li+ ions, decreasing the overpotential. In our study, when the lithium deposits pierced the membrane and deposited above the membrane, the regulatory and control effect of MoO3 to Li+ ions became invalid. After the electrospun membrane was removed by solvents, the lithium deposits on the current collector displayed rod and ellipsoidal particle morphology (Fig. 2j). Regarding the lithium deposited underneath the membrane, Fig. 2(k) showed a compact deposited lithium metal after the membrane with an areal density of 6.0 mg cm−2 was removed. The dendrite-free morphology indicated artificial diffusion layer obtained isotropy resistance for Li+ ions transport, resulting in uniform distribution of Li+ ions on the electrode/electrolyte interface. When the membrane with an areal density of 18.0 mg cm−2 was removed, abundant dendrites were observed on the current collector surface, which was induced by the greater overpotential (Fig. 2l). In the initial Li deposition process, the size of the Li nuclei and overpotential were inversely proportional. The decreased nuclei size easily induced dendrite growth [43]. These results confirmed the validity of the original design of the artificial diffusion layer whereby the Li-ion flux would be guided to pass through the artificial membrane with an increasing but uniform resistance, and the dendrite-free deposit was achieved when the optimal areal density was employed. EIS was employed to distinguish the contribution of each component or each process to the total resistance. The typical impedance spectra of the cell fabricated by the coated electrode were characterized by two semicircles and a short line (Fig. 3 a). The corresponding equivalent circuit consisted of two capacitor-type constant phase elements in parallel with resistive ones and a Warburg-type constant phase element [44], providing a good fit with the experimental results as illustrated in both Nyquist (Fig. 3a) and Bode (Fig. 3b) plots. The impedance behavior of the two parallel resistor–capacitor circuits were shown as two separated arcs in the high (102–104 Hz) and medium (100–101 Hz) frequency ranges (Fig. 3a, b), which represent the charge-transfer reaction and SEI film, respectively [45,46]. This assignment was further supported by the observation that the size of the medium-frequency semicircle showed only a slight change, whereas that of the high-frequency semicircle increased considerably with areal density, which was consistent with an increase in the polarization voltage. The reduced active area of the electrode was considered to be the critical factor in this trend. The Warburg impedance in the low-frequency range (<100 mHz) (Fig. 3a, b) arose from diffusion of Li+ ions in the polymer matrix/network and was only observed in the impedance spectra of cells with a coated electrode. This indicated a slashed diffusion rate of the increased arc length at high frequencies both led to increased polarization during the charging/discharging cycles (Fig. 2a–c). As the areal density increased, the SEI and Warburg resistances showed few changes, whereas the ohmic resistance of the bulk electrolyte and the charge-transfer resistance at the interface displayed a significantly positive correlation with it (Fig. 3a), which was in accordance with the electrochemical performances and the observed morphologies shown in Fig. 2. The mass fraction of MoO3 nanoparticles in electrospun fibers is also a critical factor in polarization overpotential and electrochemical performance. As shown in Fig. 4 , the hybrid membranes with MoO3 fraction of 3.0 wt%, 5.0 wt%, and 8.0 wt% led to different lifetimes when applied to lithium electrodes in Cu|Li half cells. PSf/MoO3-5 showed the most stable and longest lifetime of 270 cycles with the coulombic efficiency above 90% among the three. The voltage–time curves (Fig. S2) indicated that MoO3 particles helped reduce the polarization overpotential which was proved close relationship with electrochemical performance in the section of areal density. Too many MoO3 particles, however, cannot result in further decrease in the value. 3.3 Dendrite-free morphology of deposited lithium on the coated electrode Cells with different lithium deposition capacities were disassembled, and the morphologies of the Li deposits were investigated through SEM, which visually exhibit the dendrite suppression effect of the artificial SEI. To research the initial Li deposition stage, half-cells with coated and bare electrodes were discharged at 0.1 mAh cm−2. A closely packed ellipsoidal nucleus were observed when the artificial diffusion layer was removed (Fig. 5 a). The evenly distributed nucleus indicated a uniform Li-ion flux on the electrode, which was assisted by the MoO3 nanoparticles in the fibers. As compared, the Li+ ions deposition track was affected by the uneven electric field on the bare electrode surface, and an irregularly island- and wire-like nuclei was displayed (Fig. 5d). The messy Li deposits on the bare electrode turned to aggravate the uneven electric field [47]. The nucleus is critical to the following deposition stage: Li+ ions tend to adsorb and deposit on the surface of existing nuclei because of the low energy barrier [433]. Thus, the ellipsoidal particles on the coated electrode overlapped and were stacked together, displaying a multilayer morphology as the deposition capacity increased to 0.5 mAh cm−2 (Fig. 5b). When the deposition capacity was 1.0 mAh cm−2, a flat and packed morphology was observed (Fig. 5c). By contrast, the irregular Li nucleus on the bare electrode induced dendrite growth when the lithium deposited at 0.5 mAh cm−2 (Fig. 5e) and 1.0 mAh cm−2 (Fig. 5f). The dendrite-free morphology was attributed to the homogenous deposition rate, which was derived from the isotropous diffusion layer. The ideal areal density (6.0 mg cm−2) confined the thus regulating the uniformly distribution of Li+ ions on the electrode surface. 3.4 Electrochemical performance of the coated electrode Coulombic efficiency (CE), which is the ratio of dissolution capacity to deposition capacity, is a major index used to investigate the loss of Li on the working electrode [48]. In this study, an electrochemical test was conducted with half-cells by first fixing the deposition capacity of lithium at 1.0 mAh cm−2, and then extracting the lithium up to 0.5 V at different current densities. Fig. 6 demonstrated that the electrochemical performance of the coated electrode was superior to that of the bare electrode. At a current density of 0.5 mA cm−2, the coated electrode displayed a remarkable initial CE of 99.3% and remained above 90% for approximately 600 cycles. Although the bare electrode showed a similar initial CE of 96.7%, it dropped to 90% in fewer than 150 cycles. The superior electrochemical performance is attributed to the dendrite-free morphology on the electrode. The compact and flat deposited lithium leads to a stable electrode/electrolyte interface, which inhabit the irreversible parasitic reaction and the formation of “dead” Li [49]. It is accepted that the dendrites easily grow at high current densities. Our study revealed that when the current density increase to 1.0, 2.0, and 5.0 mA cm−2, cells with bare electrodes displayed fluctuant CE and inferior lifecycles, which was induced by dendrites growth. The dendrites broke the in suit SEI and irreversibly react with the electrolyte. In addition, a “dead” Li is formed once the dendrites are wrapped by the reformed SEI and lack contact with the electrode [50,51]. Lithium depletion is a critical factor in decreasing coulombic efficiency [24]. By contrast, cells with coated electrodes rendered CE above 90% for approximately 270, 170, and 90 cycles, indicating that the artificial diffusion layer regulated Li+ ions deposition and inhibited dendrite growth even at a high current density. The interface stability was further researched in the Li|Li symmetrical configuration (Fig. 7 ). A polarization test was performed at a constant current density of 2.0 mA cm−2 and a fixed areal capacity of 1.0 mAh cm−2. Cells with coated electrodes obtained 60 mV initial overpotential, which was 26 mV higher than that of bare electrodes. The additional overpotential was induced by the increased interfacial resistance. By contrast, the additional voltage polarity had a slight impact on the electrochemical performance. Due to the stable electrode/electrolyte interface, the coated electrode cycled for 300 h with negligible change in overpotential. Nevertheless, the overpotential of the bare electrode became fluctuant at 120 h and even up to 285 mV. The sharp increase in voltage polarity was caused by dendrite growth and “dead” Li formation. The artificial diffusion layer was applied to the LiFePO4|Li full-cell configuration to evaluate its practicability. A test was performed with a current rate of 2.0 C and a voltage cut-off of 2.0 V for discharging and 4.2 V for charging. Fig. 8 (a) showed that the cells with coated electrodes exhibited electrochemical performances that competed with those of cells with bare electrodes. The coated electrode obtained a highly initial capacity of 155.2 mAh g−1 and maintained 80% of its initial capacity after 500 cycles. By contrast, the initial capacity of the bare electrode was only 148.3 mAh g−1 and decreased sharply to 80% after 200cycles. The voltage-capacity plots in Fig. 8(b) indicated that the stable interface of the coated electrode contributes to the higher initial capacity and higher efficiency in the cell with coated electrode compared to that of bare one. During the first cycle, the polarization potential of the cell with bare electrode was lower than that of coated electrode initially, but rapidly increased at the end of the charging/discharging step and resulted a lower charging/discharging capacity. At the 180th cycle, the polarization of bare electrode aggravated a great decrease in capacity at the end of charging/discharging step, while that of coated electrode showed small difference with that of the 1st cycle. This phenomenon indicated a higher but more stable resistance for ion diffusion in the cell with coated electrode, which was in accordance with EIS results in Fig. 3. The sudden increase of polarization overpotential at the end of each cycle for bare cells was probably resulted from dendrite morphology of deposited lithium. As lithium stripped, the tip part of lithium dendrite became electrically disconnected and isolated from the base electrode, creating an electrically inactive lithium metal volume (“dead lithium”) and irreversible capacity fading. As comparison, the dendrite-free lithium deposited on the surface of coated electrode exhibited a strong interficial connection with the electrode and led to a high reversible capacity. The rate performance (Fig. 8c) also validated the positive effects of coated electrode. In the voltage range of 2.0–4.2 V, the full-cells cycled at various current densities for 10 cycles. The full-cells with coated electrodes showed highly reversible capacities of 155, 151, 146, 129, 112, and 153 mAh g−1, and the capacity recovery was approximately 98.7%. By contrast, the control cell exhibited inferior reversible capacities of 149, 140, 132, 111, 87, and 145 mAh g−1. However, the capacities of full-cells with coated electrodes show fluctuations at high charging/discharging rates, and a further investigation is required. The mechanism on the improved performances was briefly investigated through EIS. Fig. 9 displays the Nyquist and Bode imaginary plots of Cu|Li half-cells with different cycle numbers. Two semicircles in the high-frequency range, ascribed to charge-transfer (105–103 Hz) and ion-diffusion (101–10−1 Hz) responses respectively, were observed in Fig. 9(a–c) for cells with bare electrodes. The values of the two resistances varied with cycles (Table S1), indicating an unstable electrolyte/electrode interface. At the 70th cycle, another response occurred at exceedingly low frequencies (Fig. 9c), ascribed to diffusion resistance from the large amount of dead lithium on electrode surface as Coulombic efficiency is very low after 70 cycles. As comparison, the diffusion resistance at low frequencies that originated from the hybrid membrane in cells with coated electrode showed only slight changes with cycle numbers (Table S1). Therefore, the stable resistance and dendrite-free lithium are resulted, and are considered as the dominant contributor for the long-term life cycles of half- and full-cells with coated electrodes. 4 Conclusions A PSf/MoO3 hybrid membrane was fabricated by electrospinning technology, acting as a diffusion layer on anodic electrode surfaces. An increased but stable electrode/electrolyte interfacial resistance was then resulted and became dominant instead of the non-uniform resistance originated from natural pristine SEI. The optimal areal density (6.0 mg cm−2) was determined to enable both dendrite-free morphology and deposition underneath the membrane. As observed, a lower areal density enabled deposition within fibers, thus making the diffusion layer invalid, whereas a higher areal density led to dendritic morphology due to extremely high overpotential voltage. Improved electrochemical performances were achieved. Cu|Li cells obtained remarkable lifespans for more than 600 cycles at a current density of 0.5 mA cm−2. The full-cells possessed an excellent initial capacity at 155.2 mAh g−1 and retained 80% of their original capacity after 500 cycles at 2.0 C. EIS measurements indicated that the shift of dominant resistance from ion transfer in the SEI film to both ion diffusion in the diffusion layer and charge transfer at the interface ensured this improvement, and the stable resistance was the critical factor. coredata.dc:description: A uniform diffusion layer is essential for non-dendritic deposition of lithium in high-density lithium batteries. However, natural pristine solid electrolyte interface (SEI) is always porous and inhomogeneous because of repeated breakdown and repair cycles, whereas ideal materials with excellent mechanical property for artificial SEIs remain a challenge. Herein, a robust and stable interface is achieved by spinning soft polymer associated with few MoO3 into fibers, and thus mechanical property of fibers other than materials determines mechanical performance of the interface which can be optimized by adjusting parameters. Furthermore, lithium deposited underneath the layer is enabled by constructing an optimal resistance to make the membrane serve as an artificial SEI rather than lithium host. As a result, dendrite-free lithium was observed underneath the membrane, and stable interface for long-term cycling was also indicated by EIS measurements. The lithium iron phosphate (LiFePO4) full-cell with coated electrode demonstrated an initial capacity of 155.2 mAh g−1, and 80% of its original capacity was retained after 500 cycles at 2.0 °C without any additive in carbonate-based electrolyte.

coredata.dc:title: A robust interface enabled by electrospun membrane with optimal resistance in lithium metal batteries
